sen.j: スクナビコナ（スクナヒコナとも。須久那美迦微、少彦名、少日子根など、他多数。）は、日本神話における神。
sen.e: Sukunabikona (also called Sukunahikona,
Sukunabikona (also called Sukunahikona,
Sukunabikona (also called Sukunahikona, as well as Sukunaminokami, Sukunahikona, Sukunahikone, and so on) is a god in the Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: 次セルと統合しました。

sen.j: 古事記ではカミムスビ（かみむすびのかみ）の子とされ、日本書紀ではタカミムスビ（たかみむすびのかみ）の子とされる。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) he is said to be a son of Kamimusubi (Kamimusubi-no-kami), and in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) he is said to be a son of Takamimusubi (Takamimusubi-no-kami).

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) he is said to be a son of Kamimusubi (Kamimusubi-no-kami), and in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) he is said to be a son of Takamimusubi (Takamimusubi-no-kami).

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) he is said to be a son of Kamimusubi (Kamimusubi no Kami), and in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) he is said to be a son of Takamimusubi (Takamimusubi no Kami).
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: オホクニヌシの国作りに際し、波の彼方より天乃羅摩船にのって来訪した神。
sen.e: He is a god who came on Amenokagami-no-fune Ship when Okuninushi was creating the nation.
He is a god who came on the Amenokagami-no-fune Ship when Okuninushi was creating the nation.
He is a god who came on the Amenokagami-no-fune Ship when Okuninushi was creating the nation.

sen.j: 小さいと言われているが、「鵝（ひむし・蛾）の皮の服を着ている」と高御産巣日神の「わが子のうち、指の間から落ちた子」という記述からの後世の想像である。
sen.e: Although he is said to be small, this is an imagination in later ages from the descriptions "he wears the skin of himushi (goose or a moth)" and "he is one of my children who fell from between my fingers".
sen.cmt: 鵝はガチョウ、蛾は虫のガの意味で異なるため、下記HPを参考に「ガチョウまたはガ」という訳にしました。http://www5d.biglobe.ne.jp/~tosikenn/izumomihomisaki.html
sen.e: Although he is said to be small, this came later from descriptions that "he wears the skin of himushi (goose or a moth)" and "he is one of my children who fell from between my fingers".

Although he is said to be small, this came later from descriptions that 'he wears the skin of himushi (goose or a moth)' and 'he is one of my children who fell from between my fingers' of Takamimusubi no Kami.
sen.cmt: " → ' としました。高御産巣日神 を追加しました。

sen.j: 国造りの協力神・常世の神・医薬・石・穀物霊など多様な姿を有する。
sen.e: He is described in various ways, for example as a god who cooperated in creation of the nation, an everlasting god, medicine, stone, or the spirit of the grain.
He is described in various ways, for example as a god who cooperated in creation of the nation, an everlasting god, medicine, stone, or the spirit of the grain.
He is described in various ways, for example as a god who cooperated in creation of the nation, an everlasting god, medicine, stone, or the spirit of the grain.

sen.j: ただし酒・石に関しては記述よりそうした面が見られると想像されるだけであり、あくまで性質的なものである。
sen.e: However likening to liquor and stone is merely an imagination from descriptions and refers only to his nature.
However likening to liquor and stone is merely an imagination from descriptions and refers only to his nature.
However likening to liquor and stone is merely an imagination from descriptions and refers only to his nature.

sen.j: 古事記によれば、オホクニヌシの国土造成に際し、アメノカガミノフネに乗って波間より来訪し、オホナムチ（大己貴）大神の命によって国造りに参加した。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki", Sukunabikona came on Amenokagami-no-fune Ship from between waves when Okuninushi was creating the nation and participated in the creation by order of Onamuchi.
According to "Kojiki", Sukunabikona came on Amenokagami-no-fune Ship from between waves when Okuninushi was creating the nation and participated in the creation by order of Onamuchi.
According to "Kojiki," Sukunabikona came on Amenokagami-no-fune Ship from between waves when Okuninushi was creating the nation and participated in the creation by order of Onamuchi no Okami.
sen.cmt: 大神 とありますので、 Okami を追加しました。

sen.j: 日本書紀にも同様の記述があり、記・紀以外の文献では多くは現れない神である。
sen.e: Similar description is found in "Nihonshoki" and he rarely appears in other literature than "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki".
Similar description is found in "Nihonshoki" and he rarely appears in other literature than "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki".
Similar description is found in "Nihonshoki" and he rarely appears in other literature than "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki."
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置をクォーテーションの中に移動しました。

sen.j: 創造における多様な面をもつ神ではあるが、悪童的な性格を有すると記述される（日本書紀八段一書六）。
sen.e: While he has various aspects in the creation of nation, he is described to have a personality like a naughty child.
While he has various aspects of a creator of nations, he is likened to have a personality like that of a naughty child.
While he has various aspects of a creator of nations, he is likened to have a personality like that of a naughty child (from the 6th alternate writing of Section 8 in Nihonshoki).
sen.cmt: 日本書紀八段一書六 → 6th alternate writing of Section 8 in Nihonshoki としました (定訳不明）。

sen.j: オホナムチ同様多くの山や丘の造物者であり命名神として登場する。
sen.e: Like Onamuchi, Sukunabikona appears as a creator of many mountains and hills as well as a naming god.
Like Onamuchi, Sukunabikona appears as a creator of many mountains and hills as well as a god of names.
Like Onamuchi, Sukunabikona appears as a creator of many mountains and hills as well as a god of names.

sen.j: のちに常世国へと渡り去る。
sen.e: He later leaves to Tokoyo-no-kuni (parallel universe beyond the sea).
He later leaves to Tokoyo-no-kuni (parallel universe beyond the sea).
He later leaves to Tokoyo no Kuni (parallel universe beyond the sea).
sen.cmt: Tokoyo no Kuni としました。

sen.j: 名前の由来について、古事記伝によれば「御名の須久那（スクナ）はただ大名持（オホナムチ）の大名と対であるため」とあり、名前が必ずしも体の大きさを表すわけではない。
sen.e: The source of the name Sukunabikona is, according to "Kojiki", "his name 'Sukuna' (few, little) is just in contrast with 'Ona' (many, big) of Onamuchi" and the name does not necessarily mean the size of his body.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記がなくSukuna、Onaだけではわかりにくいため、カッコ書きで説明を補足しました。
sen.e: The source of the name Sukunabikona is, according to "Kojiki", "his name 'Sukuna' (few, little) is just in contrast with 'Ona' (many, big) of Onamuchi" and the name does not necessarily mean the size of his body.

The source of the name Sukunabikona is, according to "Kojiki," his name "Sukuna" (few, little) is just in contrast with "Ona" (many, big) of Onamuchi, and the name does not necessarily mean the size of his body.
sen.cmt: 一部クォーテーションマークを変更しました。

sen.j: あるいは金井清一によれば「若き日の御子」の意とする説もある。
sen.e: Seiichi KANAI says the name means "an Imperial son in his youth".
Seiichi KANAI says the name means "an Imperial son in his youth".
Seiichi KANAI says the name means 'an Imperial son in his youth.'

sen.j: また、この神が単独ではなく、かならずオホナムチと行動を共にすることから二神の関係が古くから議論されている。
sen.e: As this god never acts alone but is always with Onamuchi, there are age-old arguments over the relations between these two gods.
As this god never acts alone but is always with Onamuchi, there are age-old arguments over the relations between these two gods.
As this god never acts alone but is always with Onamuchi, there are age-old arguments over the relations between these two gods.

sen.j: 大林太良はこの神に「第二の自我」を見、吉田敦彦は双生児的な関係を指摘している。
sen.e: Taryo OBAYASHI finds "the second self" and Atsuhiko YOSHIDA points out twin-like relation.
Taryo OBAYASHI finds "the second self" and Atsuhiko YOSHIDA points out a twin-like relation.
Taryo OBAYASHI finds 'the second self' and Atsuhiko YOSHIDA points out a twin-like relation.

sen.j: 海から来訪したとの記述により渡来人という説もあるが、船で渡来＝外国人という単純な図式からの連想であり、奇説の域を出ない。
sen.e: Though Sukunabikona is said to be a toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) because of the description that he came from over the sea, this is only an association of coming on the ship with a foreigner and does not go beyond the bounds of a unique story.

Though Sukunabikona is said to be a toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) because of the description that says he came from over the sea, this is only due to an association made from coming on a ship with a foreigner and does not go beyond the bounds of being a unique story.

Although Sukunabikona is said to be a toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) because of the description that says he came from over the sea, this is only due to an association made from coming on a ship with a foreigner and does not go beyond the bounds of being a unique story.

sen.j: 日本は古来より海のかなた、あるいは海底に浄土が存在し、そこからすべての富や知恵・命が来訪するという信仰がある。
sen.e: In Japan there is a belief from old ages that Pure Land is over the sea or in the bottom of sea and all the wealth and wisdom and life come from there.
In Japan there is a belief from old ages that the Pure Land is over the sea or in the bottom of sea and all the wealth and wisdom and life come from there.
In Japan there is a belief from old ages that the Pure Land is over the sea or in the bottom of sea and all the wealth and wisdom and life come from there.

sen.j: これは太平洋を木船で往来した縄文の頃よりの経験から生まれた伝説であり、この神もそこに由来するとされる。
sen.e: This is a legend originating from experiences from the Jomon Period and it is said Sukunabikona has the same origin.
This is a legend originating from experiences from the Jomon Period and it is said Sukunabikona has the same origin.
This is a legend originating from experiences from the Jomon period and it is said Sukunabikona has the same origin.
sen.cmt: period を小文字にしました。

tit.j: スクナビコナを祀る主な神社
tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、小文字にしました。

sen.j: 淡嶋神社 (和歌山市)（和歌山県和歌山市）

Awashima-jinja Shrine (Wakayama City) (Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture)
Awashima-jinja Shrine (Wakayama City) (Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture)

sen.e: Gojoten-jinja Shrine (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture)
Gojoten-jinja Shrine (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture)

sen.j: 酒列磯前神社（茨城県ひたちなか市）

sen.cmt: 原文では「分詞」とありますが「分祀」の誤りと判断し、用語集を参考にしました。

sen.j: 沙沙貴神社（滋賀県蒲生郡安土町）
sen.e: Sasaki-jinja Shrine (Azuchi Town, Gamo County, Shiga Prefecture)
